I read the store page before buying and knew what is was about and how to play so I knew what to expect.

It's easier for people to bash a game and attempt to crack jokes in the reviews, but when it comes to pointing out their inability to read they begin to riot in defense.

This is a game about total world destruction and your mission is to nuke other countries while trying to defend your own. Controls are simple: WASD to spin the globe, Spacebar to return home, F to attack, and R to defend.

When you start a game you'll notice floating resources all over the map. Click the resources to send drones out to collect them. Once you have enough resources you can start your assult on the enemy. Pressing F will switch to attack mode and if you click on an enemy city you are given 3 options, one is to arm a nuke, the next is to fire the nuke, and the last option is to cancel the attack (in war we don't use that button). You need to are every nuke before launching it and every nuke costs resources so collecting resources is a big part of winning.

Defending is also very important since you only have a few cities. Pressing R switches you to defensive mode where you can target incoming nukes and destroy them by firing rockets at them while in mid-flight.

Rotation of the globe can be wonky at times, but this is really the only issue I have with it. Overall it's a fun game and with such a low price there is no reason to complain, unless you just enjoy complaining.

reviewText:
The game isn't necessarily bad, but I wouldn't pay for it—but I'm a sucker for cards.


---
Game Overview:
Defend your base against other AI opponents. Collect resources in order to produce nukes to destroy enemy cities. Collect resources to defend against enemy nukes.

You rotate the globe with WASD or arrow keys.

Toggle into attack mode by pressing F.
*You can attack other bases' cities. A base is defeated when all of its cities are destroyed.
*The last base with a city or more wins.
*Cities are viewed as a group of buildings. Click on them with attack mode.
*You are given 3 options: A [arm], L [launch], C [cancel].
*You must ARM before a LAUNCH.
*Launching a nuke requires 20 resources.

Toggle into defense (resource) mode by pressing R.
*You can destroy incoming enemy nukes by clicking on them in this mode (requires 10 resources).
*You can send helicopters to pick up resources across the globe.
*Resources are viewed as lil' cubes.
*Resource amount will increase when helicopters come back with resources.

Spacebar brings the camera back to your base.


There is no variation in maps, game modes, and weapons.
There is an option for the number of enemies and the difficulty.

The visuals are moderate.

The navigation of the globe using WASD/arrow keys are a lil' funky and may need some tweaking—perhaps allow mouse control for navigation?

The sound effects were a lil' crude so I left the game muted.
---

It's not a bad game. It's not a great game.
I'd like to compare these games to F2Ps.

Is it worth paying a dollar (or a couple cents if on sale)?
No.

You'd much be better off playing TF2 or Dota 2—or even some flash games.


NOTE: I rarely post reviews, but after reading the positive reviews of this game, I felt that it's better to warn gamers of where their money goes.

reviewText:
This was gifted to me by one of my friends who like to torture me.

Graphics:
There's really not much here, aside from the character portraits and a world with missiles.  The graphics are PS2 quality in my opinion, with just small character portraits, low rendered missile, missile trails and explosions and small unregocnizable drones that gather resources.  Aside from the missiles and explosions, there's not much going to to wow about.  I should also add that when played in a window mode, after each match, the game goes back to full screen by it's self.

Sound:
There is NO music, only ambient noise on the title screen and missile launches and explosions.  That is literally ALL there is for sound.  I have no been able to get the music to work at all.

Control:
You use the WASD to move the globe around and the mouse to gather resources or fire missiles.  Sadly, navigating the globe is annoying, as sometimes you won't be able to rotate it in a certain direction, or it will just wiz by.  The mouse control seems fine.

Gameplay:
You pick from one of 8 different nations (it doesn't matter who since it seems none of them have any differances besides portrait and name), and then go about collecting small orange blocks (resources) so you can launch missiles at enemies or defend yourself from missiles.  Each attack missile costs 20 resource to fire, while defense missils cost 10, but they can be rapid fired.

You win by being the last nation standing, but you will find this difficult as it's hard to see when a missile actually is coming at you, not realizing until until after the missile hits that you were under atatck.  You will waste resources firing at missiles that were never going at you, while it will seem nothing short of a full Macross-style barrage of missiles will get through your target's defenses.

The opponents just randomly attack everyone with no seeming strategy. I tried 3 rounds with all opponents on easy and never survuved very long due to all the missiles flying around and not being able to see which ones were coming at me.  I did 1 round with a single enemy, and still missed a few missiles getting through, since it takes a few seconds for you to figure out if your defense missile stopped the enemy missile.  It also seemed like the enemies have unlimited resources from the amount of missiles and defense missiles they fire.

Regardless of wether you win or lose, nothing happens and you are chucked back to the controls screen.  Every time.  No score, no ranking.  Nothing.  There is nothing here but a lame and not as fun Missile Command ripoff.

reviewText:
Attrition: Nuclear Domination

Wow, let me first start off by saying that this game couldn't be easier to understand. As you first start the game, you are shown a comprehensive list, that details all the in-depth mechanics of the game, and how to control them. After the brief tutorial screen, you're throw right into the action, and given the freedom of choosing whatever character you want, each possessing a variety of entirely useless stats.

This game brings a whole new meaning to the 'Open-World' tag. The whole simulation is observed from a beautifully designed bird's eye perspective.

A problem I often see in Earth centric games like this; is the global navigation is very convoluted and not very efficient.
This game could not be farther from that!
Prepare to be effortlessly wisked away by your WASD keys, dragged to the far edges of the globe, so that you can defend, and return fire, with nuclear war heads.

Frequently, the devs are so busy, perfecting the engine and the mechanics of the game, that they quickly gloss over the audio and soundtrack.  NOT HERE  The game includes a collection of roughly 5 sound effects, that along with massive amounts of repitition, will have your mind beaten into submission.

All in all, with a moving soundtrack, extensive gameplay, and gentle learning curve, I am positive that this groundbreaking title will be a classic for ages!


Overall Quantitative:

Gameplay   9.5/10
Audio          5/5
Engine        10/10
Graphics     8.5/10

You send out helicopters to retrieve boxes (resources) on the globe and launch nukes at opponents' specific structures in their areas. Even at a dollar or fifty cents, it just isn't worth it.
